Long Island Cagers
Beat Hopkins, 39-29
Johns Hopkins began its two-day
Nothern basketball swing Friday
night in New York and fell victim
to Long Island University by a
score of 39-29. The Homewood
courtmen flashed a good floor game
and forced their opponents to the
limit.
High scoring honors were shared
by Piazza, Long Island forward, and
Don Kelly, each amassing 15
points. Asnis, Friedman and Newman also aided the winners on attack, while Opie Chancellor and
Leo Margolis helped pile up the
Bluejay total.

King Tut's tomb. It was a collection of gold buttons and headdress

Changes And Additions
To Exam. Schedule
Announced

Political Science 2C

No room has yet been assigned
for the Political Science 2C class,
which will take its exam in the afternoon of Monday, January 30.
On the tentative schedules the
dates for the exams of Structural
Engineering and Railroad Engineering were interchanged. The
correct dates and rooms are: Structural
Engineering, Wednesday
morning, February 1, in room 307,
Latrobe Hall; Railroad Engineering Thursday, February 2, also in
room 307, Latrobe.
Another error on the posted
schedule was the substitution of Dr.
Morill's name for that of Dr.
Murnaghan in connection with the
Math S. E. course.

Closing Hours Of Gilman
And Remsen Hall
Changed
For reasons of economy, university authorities have announced a
curtailment of power and heat in
two Hopkins buildings. Hereafter,
Remsen Hall will not be open on
Sunday at all, will be closed on Saturday at 5 p. m., and, except for authorized evening classes, will be
closed on weekdays at 7 p. m.
Gilman Hall will be closed on
Sunday at 5 p. m., on Saturday at
6 p. m., and on other days at 10
p. m. After 5 p. m. on week-days,
the only entrance to the stacks shall
be through the main reading room.

the Inter-Allied War Debts" is the
topic of the annual Junior-Senior
debate for the Adams prize, to be

Sachs, Gordon Post and Nelson
Lisansky, graduate students in Political Science, will be the judges.

One writer in 1918 said that the
noted banker was fired by an "earnest and honest ambition to serve
his country and humanity and a
passionate enthusiasm for democracy." With him in his World War
work was Daniel Willard, president
of the Johns Hopkins Board of
Trustees.
Mr. Baruch was graduated from
the College of the City of New
York in 1889. The honorary LL.D.
degree was conferred upon him in
1923 by Williams College, to which
he has donated funds for the International Institute of Politics, and
by University of Southern California in 1925. He has written many
pamphlets and several books. President Wilson awarded him the Distinguished Service Medal and Italy,
Belgium, and France have honored
him.
The Commemoration Day exercises will be held at the Peabody Institute auditorium at 11 a. m. Other
details of the event are still unknown.

Army quickly pulled away in the
second half. Hillis pushed in a rebound after Kenerick had missed a

on a scoring spree which was not

Long Island Cagers
Beat Hopkins, 39-29
Johns Hopkins began its two-day
Nothern basketball swing Friday
night in New York and fell victim
to Long Island University by a
score of 39-29. The Homewood
courtmen flashed a good floor game
and forced their opponents to the
limit.
High scoring honors were shared
by Piazza, Long Island forward, and
Don Kelly, each amassing 15
points. Asnis, Friedman and Newman also aided the winners on attack, while Opie Chancellor and
Leo Margolis helped pile up the
Bluejay total.

Changes And Additions
To Exam. Schedule
Announced

Political Science 2C

No room has yet been assigned
for the Political Science 2C class,
which will take its exam in the afternoon of Monday, January 30.
On the tentative schedules the
dates for the exams of Structural
Engineering and Railroad Engineering were interchanged. The
correct dates and rooms are: Structural
Engineering, Wednesday
morning, February 1, in room 307,
Latrobe Hall; Railroad Engineering Thursday, February 2, also in
room 307, Latrobe.
Another error on the posted
schedule was the substitution of Dr.
Morill's name for that of Dr.
Murnaghan in connection with the
Math S. E. course.

Closing Hours Of Gilman
And Remsen Hall
Changed
For reasons of economy, university authorities have announced a
curtailment of power and heat in
two Hopkins buildings. Hereafter,
Remsen Hall will not be open on
Sunday at all, will be closed on Saturday at 5 p. m., and, except for authorized evening classes, will be
closed on weekdays at 7 p. m.
Gilman Hall will be closed on
Sunday at 5 p. m., on Saturday at
6 p. m., and on other days at 10
p. m. After 5 p. m. on week-days,
the only entrance to the stacks shall
be through the main reading room.

"Should the United States Cancel
the Inter-Allied War Debts" is the
topic of the annual Junior-Senior
debate for the Adams prize, to be

Sachs, Gordon Post and Nelson
Lisansky, graduate students in Political Science, will be the judges.
